“°o

MARKET CENTER IN DOWNTOWN BALTIMORE D,

The transformation of Baltimore from dowdy, old
port city to international urban magnet is an
unparalleled development success story. While the
development of Charles Center and the Inner
Harbor is justly acclaimed, Baltimore continues to
offer sound development opportunities downtown.
Market Center is where the action is and will be.

Market Center is where downtown started in
Baltimore. This traditional retail core of one million
square feet is surrounded by vital clusters of business,
medical, cultural, educational and residential uses.

These include a favorite Baltimore attraction, the
204 year old Lexington Market; the University of
Maryland Graduate Professional Schools, the

MARKET CENTER
DEVELOPMENT

internationally acclaimed Shock Trauma Center,
University Hospital, Social Security Administration
Complex, the Charles Center office cluster, the
specialty shops and galleries on Charles Street, the
State of Maryland office complex, the Mt. Royal
cultural district, and new residential neighborhoods
in Seton Hill and the Loft District.

Market Center offers distinct advantages for
developers and investors. First, there is the Baltimore
talent for creative public/private financing. Second,
developers can depend on a predictable municipal
process. Third, within the 225-acre Market Center
area are handsome buildings which will generate
rehabilitation tax benefits. New construction poten-

NORTH MARKET CENTER e



tial is here as well, with sites available for both large
and small projects.

Many feel the priceless advantage of doing business
in Market Center is the powerful role played by
results-oriented leadership. There are four elements:
a strong and committed Mayor, an enthusiastic
volunteer business community and citizenry endors-
ing development action through the Market Center
Project Area Committee; the unique, non-profit,
quasi-public Market Center Development Corpora-
tion of Baltimore, and the full cooperation of
municipal agencies and boards.

PRATT BLVD









design concept to sound financial packaging to construc-
tion. The Corporation also has access to the expertise in
the Neighborhood Progress Administration/Department of
Housing and Community Development. Baltimore City is
justly famous for the creation of sound financial deals for
developers.

PLANNING AND
DEVELOPMENT
GOALS

Improve Physical
Appearance of Market
Center

¢ Implement public improvements to complement private
development including street tree planting, street
lighting, street and sidewalk repair, installation and
maintenance of various types of streetside promotional
graphics, banners, street furniture and other elements to
provide color, excitement, and information in the area,
and to create a sense of place.

¢ Continue to promote the already successful mandatory
facade improvement program with private property
owners, consistent with required rehabilitation
standards.

Promote Office
Development in New and

Rehabilitated Buildings
in the Mid and South Sectors
of Market Center

e Continue to increase the number of office workers in
Market Center by the development of 1 to 2.4 million
square feet of space over the next 5 to 8 years.

e Continue efforts to attract a major federal office
building, and to provide the climate for expanding office
use by the State of Maryland.

® Assist developers in attracting tenants for new or
rehabilitated buildings.

Promote Residential
Development in New and
Rehabilitated Buildings in
the North and South Sectors
of Market Center

e Continue residential development linking historic
districts of Seton Hill and Mount Vernon to complete a
new in-town neighborhood.

e Continue residential development in the Loft District to
create more in-town neighborhood housing.

Revitalize Existing Retail
Activity and Create the
Climate for New Upscale
Shopping

® Encourage selected new retail development projects.

e Attract more retail customers from surrounding areas by
providing improved pedestrian and vehicular access into
the area; increasing bus service, extending hours of
Metro service and supporting Metro line expansion;
constructing new parking facilities; creating amenities;
and stimulating area promotions.

® Create a “captive market” of retail customers through
office and residential development and other appropriate
people-producing activities.

Preserve Historic Structures
Through Rehabilitation

¢ Bring together building owners and potential developers
to recycle existing buildings for positive economic use.

e Encourage rehabilitation of national register quality
buildings into uses which would preserve the historic

4. Brexton Plaza: New mixed-use office building at the
north end of Howard Street.
5.Seton Mews: In-fill development of 20 new
townhouses and rehabilitation of 50 condominiums in
historic buildings.
6. The Congress: Rehabilitation of an historic hotel for
48 apartments and restaurant use.
Mayfair Club: Rehabilitation of an historic movie
palace for health and indoor tennis club.
7.Bank of Baltimore: Rehabilitation of a six-story
warehouse for bank’s operations center and 675
employees.
8. Franklin Court: Thirty apartments in historic houses
around a courtyard facing a park.
9.McDonald’s — Penn Lumber: Rehabilitation of
historic buildings for commercial use.
10. Y.W.C.A.: Historic rehabilitation of this downtown
institution.
11. Comfort Inn Hotel: Rehabilitation of the old
YMC.A. into a 200-room hotel.
12. Enoch Pratt Free Library: Renovation of the
interior and exterior of Baltimore’s renowned Central
Library.

MID MARKET CENTER

tation and development of new mid to high-rise
projects.

¢ Convenience Retail: Integrated with residential pro-
jects or development of a 3/4-block site for a mixed-
use; available on a lease basis from owner.

e Asian Retail Development: Potential for rehabilita-
tion and new construction to create an Asian specialty
center.

Car Care Center: To serve west side of Downtown.

e Maryland Historical Society Residential Project:
High-rise quality residential project on a square block
in the Mt. Vernon historic district along with specialty
retail, parking and museum expansion.

e Maryland General Hospital: Potential mixed-use
development opportunity for rehabilitation and new
construction of property owned by the hospital.

e Office Project Above the Metro Station: Con-
struction of a 100,000-200,000 square foot office
building to house headquarters of State Mass Transit
Administration and other related governmental
agencies and street-level retail.

e Other Development Opportunities: Approxi-
mately 77,000 square feet of vacant or underutilized
corner sites for quality commercial development.



Recent and Current
Development

16. Saratoga State Center: Rehabilitation by Baltimore
City of the old Hutzler’s Department Store into
120,000 square feet of office space for a major State
agency and 20,000 square feet retail.

17. One Market Center: UMTA Joint Development
project at the Lexington Market Metro Station involv-
ing 200,000 square feet of office and retail, including
70,000 square feet for Hutzler’s new department store.

18. Hecht Company Department Store: Rehabilitation
of 129,000 square feet of the store’s interior and
exterior, plus renovation of 75,000 square feet on the
top three floors for office use.

19. Epstein’s Department Store: Interior and major
exterior rehabilitation of a 90,000 square foot depart-
ment store.

20. Lexington Market Arcade: Major addition to the
204 year old Lexington Market with food stalls, a
restaurant, entertainment area and sit down eating
space. The existing 88-stall Lexington Market East
building was also rehabilitated.

21. Lexington Mall: One block expansion of the existing
two-block pedestrian mall.

22.Howard Street Transit Mall: Twelve-block
streetscape and utility reconstruction project with
emphasis on a two-block pedestrian/transit mall at
the Lexington Mall crossing.

23. Market Center Garage: 740-car parking structure
featuring direct access into the Lexington Market.
24.100 N. Eutaw Street: A rehabilitated 30,000 square

foot building for State office use.



25. Master Hosts Inn: Complete renovation of a
120-room hotel.

26. Baltimore Street Garage: Privately developed new
garage structure for 500 cars.

27.Department of Education Office Building:
Rehabilitation of an 11-story building into headquarters
for this major State agency.

28. Murdock Place-Professional Center: Rehabilita-
tion of a 25,000 square foot historic building for head-
quarters and professional office.

29. Charles Center: Park Charles, a mixed-use project,
the last to be completed in nearby Charles Center, and
One Center Plaza, a new 180,000 square foot office
building.

30. Lexington Mall — Liberty Street Crossing:
Reconstruction of this link between Market Center
and Charles Center, including major public art work.

Future Opportunities

e Parcel I-C: UMTA Joint Development Project site
adjacent to the Metro Station for a 500,000-1,000,000
square foot office tower, retail, and garage.

e Parcel II: Development of 200,000-400,000 square foot
office towers above retail and sub-surface garage abut-
ting the Lexington Market Arcade.

¢ Hotel-Conference Center: Potential for new
development, including the rehabilitation of two
historic register quality banks and a movie palace for
conference, entertainment and meeting facilities.

¢ (Clay Street Mixed-Use Development: Potential
for high-rise residential, retail, and office adjacent to
Charles Center.

SOUTH MARKET CENTER



Recent and Current
Development

31. Baltimore Arena and Garage: Major renovation
of the former Civic Center, including new exterior
architecture, plaza, interior improvements, and a new
800-space garage.

32.Inner Harbor West: Development adjacent to
Market Center includes the new Baltimore Plaza Hotel,
Days Inn Hotel, Cabot, Cabot and Forbes office build-
ing, two City financed garages and the Festival Hall.

33. Paca-Pratt Building: Historic renovation of two loft
buildings totalling 365,000 square feet and construction
of a new 140,000 square foot building in-between for
First National Bank’s operations center.

34. Greenhouse Loft Apartments: Renovation of an

44 .Maryland Bar Association Headquarters: Renova-
tion of 30,000 square foot historic elementary school
for the Bar Association Headquarters and private
attorney offices.

45. Tuerk House: New 50,000 square foot building to
house University of Maryland Medical Systems’
substance abuse programs.

46. Pearl Street Garage: New 700-space parking garage
for University of Maryland and general public use,
including commercial space on street level.

47.Hope Lodge and Ronald McDonald House: New
construction of two buildings to accommodate Univer-
sity Hospital out-patients and their families.

48. Rieman Block: Rehabilitation of eight historic
rowhouses into 27 apartments.

49. Market Center Post Office: A new Post Office
building and public plaza.

50. University Mews: An historic rehabilitation and
infill construction for mixed-use as retail, office and
residential.

in Market Center

¢ Encourage ongoing and new seasonal promotional
events, festivities, and ethnic festivals.

¢ Continue Public Art Program to place and integrate art

e Create a warm, safe, comfortable ambiance for shoppers,
strollers, office workers and residents.

building for 91 residential units and retail on street

37.Classic Building: Rehabilitation of historic loft
building for 41 residential units and street level retail.

38. Redwood Square: Renovation of a loft building into
45 rental apartments.

39. Sailcloth Factory: Historic rehabilitation of the
Gandy Building into 107 apartments.

40. University of Maryland Professional Center:
Major renovation of 105,000 square foot loft building
for University of Maryland Medical System’s out-
patient clinic.

41. Paca-Redwood Building: Renovation of a 21,000
square foot loft building for bank, restaurant and
office use.

42. Redwood Streetscape: Reconstruction of a loft
district street for pedestrians, including major public-art
work.

43.Shock-Trauma Center: New $34.4 million, 72-bed
building for the internationally recognized Maryland
Institute for Emergency Medicine Services Sytems.

e Parcel 3/4: Special “gateway site” for new high-rise
office or residential over parking and street level retail.

e Parcel I1I: Potential for 300,000-1,000,000 square
feet of office development in the air-rights above the
1,100-parking space Lexington Market West Garage.

e Parcel 6: Mixed-use development for office, residen-
tial, retail, garage, car rental firms, and commuter bus
station, on a key two acre site adjacent to Inner
Harbor West.

¢ Rehabilitation Opportunities: Several remaining
historic loft buildings suitable for conversion into
residential or office uses.

e Post Office Plaza Area: Potential to rehabilitate
and in-fill surrounding rowhouses for residential and
retail use.

e UMAB BioTechnology Center: Conversion of
186,000 square feet warehouse for research and
manufacturing.

e Other Development Opportunities: Approximate-
ly 60,000 square feet of vacant or underu
sites for development of residential, and ¢ (\384‘{'
